cs189 & i are sitting in our cs189 system administration class right now
iptables is the firewall. its built into the kernel
you can modify its rules manually using the iptables command or use a graphical one like firestarter
all ports are technically open by default, but nothing listens on any of them by default. if you start a service like sshd, itll listen on its port and the rest will reject all data
nothing listens on any ports by default, so nothing can get in

if someone was already in there...somehow...like if you installed a trojan or something and it's phoning home... it could send info, but nobody can get in unless there's a service listening (like ssh) and they get in through that service (and ssh is about the only one that's going to let htem execute commands on your box) but by default there's no ssh server installed anyway.  you're 100% secure by default
at least as far as remote is concerned...
with physical access, there's no such thing as security
